{{cpp/chrono/file_clock/title|to_utc|from_utc}}
{{cpp/chrono/file_clock/navbar}}
{{dcl begin}}
{{dcl|num=1|since=c++20|notes={{mark tooltip|optional|provided only if to_sys and from_sys are not provided}}|
template&lt; class Duration &gt;
static std::chrono::utc_time&lt;/* see below */&gt;
    to_utc( const std::chrono::file_time&lt;Duration&gt;&amp; t );
}}
{{dcl|num=2|since=c++20|notes={{mark tooltip|optional|provided only if to_sys and from_sys are not provided}}|
template&lt; class Duration &gt;
static std::chrono::file_time&lt;/* see below */&gt;
    from_utc( const std::chrono::utc_time&lt;Duration&gt;&amp; t );
}}
{{dcl end}}

@1@ Converts the {{tt|file_time}} {{c|t}} to a {{tt|utc_time}} representing the same point in time.
@2@ Converts the {{tt|utc_time}} {{c|t}} to a {{tt|file_time}} representing the same point in time.

The duration of the return type is computed from {{tt|Duration}} in an unspecified manner.

These function templates are optional: an implementation may choose to instead provide {{rlpf|to from sys|to_sys}} and {{rlpf|to from sys|from_sys}}.

===Return value===
@1@ A {{tt|utc_time}} representing the same point in time as the argument.
@2@ A {{tt|file_time}} representing the same point in time as the argument.

===Notes===
User code should usually use {{c/core|std::chrono::clock_cast}}, which provides a generic interface to convert time points between clocks, rather than call these functions directly.
